Rob: So, I'm Rob High. I’m the IBM Fellow
Vice President and CTO for IBM Edge Computing.

Off Camera: So, I want to start with a question
on Edge - so, why edge and why edge now?

Rob: So, imagine that you're a manufacturer,
and one of things that you're trying to deal

with is the potential cost for outages in
your production line the cost that might occur

if any of your equipment goes down and stops
the production process. Or imagine that you’re

a bank and you've got hundreds of ATMs distributed
across the city and part of your responsibility

is to monitor the use of those ATMs and the
people your clients to come into that and

the potential for them to either be affected
by other people, by the potential for your

ATM to be robbed or vandalized, and the responsibility
that you have for securing protecting your

clients. Or imagine that you are an automobile
industry manufacturer and you're trying to

enhance the experiences in your car, you're
trying to engage your clients, your passengers,

your drivers, into a better driving experience,
or to give them the ability to understand

the features of your car in ways that the
manual doesn't really offer by itself.

All these examples are possible, made possible,
we can improve on those examples …

All these examples lend themselves to being
enhanced and extended using analytics, using

AI, to infuse a better experience into the
car driving environment, or to do a better

job of predicting the potential for your equipment
to fail, or to do a better job identifying

the potential for vandals to come into an
ATM vestibule.

That/the analytic though has the problem that
it needs to run locally - it needs to occur

with lower latency, it needs to be performed
without requiring a whole bunch of data to

flow back to the cloud or to your IT datacenter.
We need to take advantage of the compute capacity

that exists in those environments, to be able
to perform the analytic that’s there, to

enhance the experience, to be able to recognize
the potential for somebody come into vandalized

the machines, recognize the potential machine
to fail, and be able to respond to that in
real time.

Off Camera: So, what about the environment
makes today the time to act on edge - why
now now? what what's one thing about?

Rob: One of things that we observe about the
industry right now is that more and more of

the equipment that we use in our everyday
lives – whether those are ATMs, connected

vehicles, intelligent machines on the manufacturing
floor - all of these pieces of equipment are

now being manufactured with compute capacity,
and the compute capacity is growing. So, the

opportunity to bring some of its analytic
and operated on the equipment is surfacing,

and innovations around that are being driven
based on the need to improve quality and enhanced
value.

The issue is: how are you going to be able
to manage the deployment of workloads that

perform these kinds of actions in the presence
of all that compute capacity and all the opportunity

that now exists, to use that equipment with
its embedded intelligence to influence the

way that your employees, your customers, your
business, operates in the operating environment
that matters to you.

Off Camera: What has prevented customers from
embracing this edge or embracing these technologies
up until now?

Rob: To some of the opportunity is just emerging
as equipment gets created with more and more

compute capacity, with computers that are
open, so the idea of being able to exploit

this capability is relatively new, but it's
also introduces, it also …

But it also introduces new challenges. If
you think about the number of equipment than
a …

If you think about how much equipment now
exists in the marketplace - we estimate there's

about fifteen billion intelligent devices
in the marketplace today - and how much of

that is going to grow over time, you begin
to realize that the issues are:

* how do you get the right software to the
right place at the right time?

* how do you manage the diversity of your
equipment?

* how do you deal with the dynamics of the
environment in which this equipment operates?
* how do you do so securely?

These are all issues that, that the industry
faces today and for which we need to solve

in order for you, and the rest of the industry,
to take advantage of this new ability that
now has surfaced.

Off Camera: I want to go on a little more
so tell me a little bit more about the latency,

the management complexity, and the security
compliance issues that customers are facing

today preventing them from getting to the
edge.

Rob: So, to be able to take advantage of the
AIs and analytics that could be used in the

context of the problems that you're trying
to solve, we need to deal with the issues

of latency. Many of these examples require
that the analytic respond in real time. If

you've got a visual analytic that you're deploying
on to an automobile, let's say, and that analytic

is responsible for recognizing the potential
for a dangerous driving situation to occur,

that analysis has to occur in real time, it
has to occur even if the network is down,

it has to occur without incurring a great
deal of bandwidth cost, and has to be able

to do so securely. These are the issues that
are driving the need to run many of the analytic

locally on the equipment itself - to reduce
latency, to reduce the amount of bandwidth

required to be able to perform some these
activities, to be able to do so even when

the connections to the cloud in the IT data
centers are broken, to be able to do so in

a way that’s secure and responsive to the
people that are out there.

Off Camera: So, moving the conversation to
IBM, what is IBM specifically doing to help

address these challenges, and what is IBM
bringing to clients to take advantage of today.

Rob: So, recognizing these issues, IBM has
focused on four disciplines: number one, the

ability to manage the problem, manage the
distribution of software at massive scale,

to be able to do so without requiring the
addition of many more administrators to be

able to get the right software to the right
place at the right time. We're focusing on

open source and creating an ecosystem so that
we can get a whole community of developers

and manufacturers and software development
organizations involved in creating capabilities

that are not only useful to you, but also
handle the diversity of equipment and devices

that are out there on the marketplace. We're
focusing on the problems security by addressing

not only insuring that the right workloads
are on the right machine at the right time,

but that if anybody attempts to tamper with
that we can recognize it immediately and automatically

handle remediation of those security issues
- and we're focusing on user experiences by

taking our large portfolio of other services
that we’ve created in the cloud. For example,

some of the AI services we've created within
Watson, or the work that we've done around

visual analytics in the intelligent IOT space,
or the work that we've been doing around data

and data analytics and the tools are associated
with managing models in production environments,

and bringing that capability to the edge so
that we can build solutions faster with reliable

technologies that have been proven in the
industry before and from which we can create
value at a higher rate.

Off Camera: And what about the service side
of it? I believe we're gonna have some dedicated

services support for folks to help accelerate
their edge transformation?

Rob: So, we've been focusing on both the software
platform that enables for the creation of

enterprise applications that are deployed
on the edge, managing those workflows into

the right locations, but we’re coupling
that with expert services. People who not

only understand the issues a system of the
architecture of edge computing, but more specifically

understand the industry application of edge
computing and how to solve real business problems

quickly, reliably, using techniques that been
proven so that we can repeat that not only

for you but so that you in turn can then get
into a reliable system to solve your problems
quicker.

Off Camera: And I know IBM and Red Hat just
talked about or announced the hybrid multicloud

platform. How does this play into the hybrid
multicloud platform work now that we are rolling
out along with our partners at Red Hat?

Rob: To make it possible for us to do what
we are doing an edge computing we're drawing

on the best practices that have been developed
in cloud computing. Cloud computing both in

the public cloud as well as in our experiences
with hybrid cloud. The acquisition of Red

Hat brings a tremendous grounding foundation
to what we're doing in the hybrid cloud computing

space, and that's a grounding that we can
now draw into edge computing. Edge servers

can be based on both Red Hat Enterprise Linux,
it can be based on OpenShift, we can build

on that core technology to enhance the value
that is delivered in Edge servers. We can

also draw from our experiences with DevOps,
with continuous integration and continuous
delivery.

To automate the processes for deploying new
workloads that are created all the way through

to being deployed into the edge environment
- both on edge servers, as well as edge devices

- so this relationship that we have formed
now with the Red Hat team give us a really

incredible foundation from which we can take
all the work and investment that you've made,

that we have made, that others have made,
in the hybrid cloud space and draw that out
to the edge.

Off Camera: What about - this all sounds great,
but when I think about competitors – Microsoft,

AWS, Google - what is IBM bringing to the
table today to beat those three or to to differentiate

our competitors along security of management
and latency issues that you mentioned?

Rob: So, the good news here is that the entire
industry has woken up to the idea that edge

computing is going to bring value to businesses
like yours. That also means there’s competition

out there. In my opinion competition is good
- I'd rather compete on the quality of what
we deliver than to be in business if we can't.
Said differently…

I'd rather that we be able to compete on the
quality of our technology - and part of the

quality that we bring to the table includes
our ability to minister and manage the deployment

of workloads in a very diverse and very dynamic
world at enormous scales. Not only recognizing

that you will have many machines deployed
in the edge computing space, but your use

of those machines will vary from one day to
the next, for one situation to the next, and

there's all kinds of changes that you're undergoing
even as you operate your business. These are

the characteristics that we've embodied into
this offering around edge computing.

So, to be able to do that without adding more
administrators is key to be able to scale

the solution at reasonable cost, without incurring
more expense as you begin to move out into

these edge locations. We have focused on the
issues of security, recognizing that not only

do edge computing environments expand the
tax surfaces, but also recognizing that we

can draw from our experiences in securing
cloud computing and make that available in

these environments - protecting the workload,
signing them, verifying their, their, accuracy
at that …

Signing the workloads and verifying that they
continue to be valid and have integrity in

the operating environment and automatically
responding to it to the system in the case

we recognize a change has been made that was
not authorized.

We focused on the problems of leveraging the
underlying security of the operating system,

the hardware that exists in these operating
environments, building on that to secure the

protection of workloads in the edge, and putting
an emphasis on on the people that are involved

in maintaining some separation concerns while
at the same time allowing multiple stakeholders

to be involved in deployment of workloads
on the devices. So that for the same device

you may have won a stakeholder they is focused
on the warranty requirements so that device,

you may have others that are more interested
in the operating parameters of that device.

You may have some stakeholders responsible
for the maintenance and management of that

device, as well as those that are responsible
for calibrating and certifying those devices.

And each of them can bring their own set of
interests, being able to support all the stakeholders

operating with the device concurrently, while
still maintaining separation concerns and

isolating their interest is key to what we've
been able to bring.

Off Camera: And what it be safe to say that
IBM is the only player in the space that lets

you build applications and workloads to run
across any public cloud and still run them

at the edge, about being locked to a single
vendor, to a single environment in your enterprise?

Rob: So, drawing on our experience with hybrid
cloud computing where we have recognized the

importance to you, to be able to manage your
workloads across multiple different cloud

vendors, to be able to understand what each
of those different components are doing, to

make sure that the right workloads are … placed
in the right cloud environment, now is something

that we can leverage in the edge computing
space - which not only gives us the ability

to extend that same management paradigm across
multiple cloud providers, but also to be able

to enable for multiple participants in creating
value in the edge computing space to be able

to maintain our heterogeneous support for
a very vibrant ecosystem.

Off Camera: I want to shift and talk a little
bit before you wrap up about the use cases

and and what you've seen so far, no client
name, so what are what are some clients who

are interested in this technology you know
what are they using or for what what do you

think they might use IBM technology for and
and why IBM is is right partner for them.

Rob: Some of the key use cases that we have
been observing a participating in include

things like putting a camera on a piece of,
of uh …

…includes things like putting a camera on
a piece of manufacturing equipment and using

that camera and analytic running on a camera,
to recognize the quality of product coming

off the machine and to be able to use that
then to instruct the process, the manufacturing

process, to remove a product that is sub-quality,
to do that in real time, and at the at the
rate at which production is being performed.

Another example is work that could be done
in increasing the value and the user experiences

in automobiles and, and mining equipment,
and other kinds of vehicles that are used

within industrial settings. To be able to
use the compute capacity on the vehicle to

recognize whether that vehicle’s operating
at peak performance or has a potential for
failure or to, to …

… or to enable the driver or the equipment
operator to use that equipment more effectively

to understand its features and what can be
done with it to be able to perform the tasks
that need to get performed.

Another example is where we’re using, again,
video analytics to recognize encroachment

into dangerous situations. Whether that's
on the manufacturing floor, and recognizing

workers that are maybe getting too close to
the manufacturing processes of the equipment

that is being used there, in a mine, being
able to recognize when somebody maybe encroaching

on a blast zone just before rock is being
blasted out of, out of a uh …

So, using video analytics to recognize people
encroaching into a dangerous situation whether

that's on the manufacturing floor, getting
too close to the equipment, or getting too
close to the blast zone in a mining environment.

Off Camera: And then what it be safe to say
that, for all these enterprises that are looking

at edge, there's really a couple values but
it's really a value to the business at the

end of the day that makes things faster, helps
them drive revenue, or save money, and it
really makes their end user experience stronger?

Rob: So, all these use cases are fun and interesting,
but the more important pie …

All these these cases are fun and interesting,
but the more important point is that they

they result in lowering the cost of operations
- for example, by removing the cost of an

outage by predicting the potential for a piece
of equipment to fail and avoid that being,

… that failure occurring in the middle of
production line run.

Or, they increase the user experience and
therefore the value of the product that you're
creating, which includes of course, …

Or, they increase the value of the product
by enhancing the user experience on that product,

or to adding features that are useful in selling
that product to your marketplace. Or, they

increase productivity which allows you then
to operationalize some of the advantages that

these at new, new pieces of equipment are
bringing to the table.

Or, they enhance the value …

Or, they increase the productivity of your
operations by making your workers more effective

at the task that they needed to get done,
or to recognize conditions that they can respond
to as they're occurring in real time.

Off Camera: So, for for people interested,
what is it that they can buy today out from

IBM and get started with taking advantage
of this technology today?

Rob: So, these capabilities are being offered
by IBM in a product that we call IBM Edge

Computing. IBM Edge Computing for Servers,
IBM Edge Computing for Devices - both of which

enable us to manage the distribution of workloads
into either servers or devices - on your factory

floor, in your hotel building, in your retail
store, in your bank - in all these locations
where edge computing is being performed.

and mention Cloud Pak? So how can customers
take advantage of this technology today?
Rob: So, these bill these …

So, these capabilities are being offered by
IBM through an offering that we refer to as

IBM Cloud Pak for Edge Computing. This has
a couple variations including support for

edge servers as well as edge devices, both
of which enable us to deploy and manage workloads

into these devices, into these servers, at
massive scale with security and integrity,

and be able to manage the diversity and dynamism
of those edge computing environments.

Yeah so so why edge now, and you can tell

Rob: So, edge computing is emerging in many
different industries today, in many different

ways, and largely because … the equipment
is used in different industries whether that's

manufacturing or retail, banking, travel and
transportation, the equipment now is being
enhanced with compute capacity.

So, let's take manufacturing as an example.
One of the issues that you might want to run
it …

So, let's take manufacturing as an example.
Imagine that you're trying to run a production

line and one of the problems you're trying
to solve for is: how do you avoid outages

because your equipment has a potential failing
in the middle of a production run? That could

easily cost hundreds of thousands, perhaps
even millions of dollars an hour, if you have
an impound unplanned …

That could easily cost hundreds of thousand
dollars or millions of dollars an hour if

you have an unplanned outage in the middle
the production line.

So, how do we solve for that? Put an acoustic
or visual analytic on the machine that recognizes

the potential for that machine to fail, that
listens to the noise of the bearings are making,

or the fans are making, or that the motor
is is creating, … and listen for those sounds

that .. may be indicative of a future failure
in this machine. Using the analytic, predict

that potential to fail, so you can then schedule
maintenance on that between production runs.

Now, of course that has to be done with very
low latency. You have to be able to do that

at the machine, in real time - and you need
to do that without driving a whole bunch of
data back to the cloud to do that analytic.

So simply because the cost of that analytic
is too high, sorry, simply because the cost
of transferring the data is too high.

So, with edge computing we can bring that
analytic and perform it right there on the

machine itself. We can reduce the latency,
we can decrease the amount of bandwidth that’s

required, we can improve the security and
the protection of the data that’s produced

off that machine. We can look for enhancements
in user experiences on that machine that delivers

the value of being able to reduce that cost
over time.

Rob: So, keep in mind IOT has been around
for a good long time, and the tradition of

IOT has been to connect sensors and actuators
to be able to connect and collect that data,

bring it back to, let's say a data cloud,
and use that to analyze the potential for

that data to mean something to you. You could
put sensors on a bridge and use that to analyze

the potential for that bridge to fail at some
point. And this is been very useful to our

industry. The problem has been, number one:
the amount of data that goes back to the cloud

for that purpose is underutilized. In fact,
we estimate that are probably only about one

percent of the data comes into the cloud from
IOT sensors ever gets used in any actionable

way - but the data that's being produced continues
to rise at an exponential rate.

So, with cloud computing combined with edge
computing, we can now begin to place the workloads

in a more meaningful location for near time,
low latency, low bandwidth, real time analytic

we can put that analytic on the machine itself
- and, with the increasing capacity of compute

on these IOT devices, we have the ability
to do that now.

That doesn't mean the data doesn’t still
go to the cloud.

It just means that the data that does go to
the cloud has already been pre-rendered, has

all been filtered, it's been qualified, and
so the data that end up in the cloud represents

a … a cleaner aggregation from which you
can do things like trend analysis or recognize,

you know, something that may be anomalous
in your fleet - things that you can at compute
at a more macro …

Things you can compute on a more macro level
so the whole world of IOT is evolving and,

specifically with the introduction to edge
computing, giving us now the opportunity to

put the right information at the right place,
put the right workloads in the right place,
to do the job that’s needed more effectively.

Off Camera: Well the last question do we want
to touch on the relationship to 5G. and edge

at all?
(Sure)

Rob: Now interestingly, this is all happening
at the same time as 5G is started to surface.

5G is driving a tremendous transformation
in both the network industry as well as within

business organizations. In fact, 5G is probably
going to disproportionately advantage businesses

as opposed to consumers who are advantaged
by things like 4G and 3G.

But 5G also introduces certain promises like
lower latency and higher bandwidth. Both of

which really can only be achieved by moving
workloads closer to the end point by moving
the workload in …

By moving the workload to locations in the
network that reduce the distance between the

input of the device and where the analytic
is been performed - in the network, in the
edge server, or on the edge device itself.
